abstract: Critics want to know why the agency that regulates automakers did not act more aggressively against Toyota.
snippet: Critics want to know why the agency that regulates automakers did not act more aggressively against Toyota.
lead_paragraph: In November, top auto safety officials made an unusual request of Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood. After reviewing complaints about Toyota vehicles, the regulators said they believed the automaker was stalling their inquiries and wanted to go to Japan to stress just how serious their concerns had become.

headline.main: Safety Agency Scrutinized as Toyota Recall Grows
headline.print_headline: As Toyota’s Recall Expands, Safety Agency Is in Cross Hairs

byline.original: By Eric Lichtblau and Bill Vlasic

abstract: Adam Bryant, deputy business editor of The Times discusses Toyota's crisis and its latest recall, the Prius hybrid.
snippet: Adam Bryant, deputy business editor of The Times discusses Toyota's crisis and its latest recall, the Prius hybrid.
lead_paragraph: Adam Bryant, deputy business editor of The Times discusses Toyota's crisis and its latest recall, the Prius hybrid.

abstract: Investors in collateralized mortgage obligations could be in for trouble if interest rates increase, causing a sharp fall in the value of these products.
snippet: Investors in collateralized mortgage obligations could be in for trouble if interest rates increase, causing a sharp fall in the value of these products.
lead_paragraph: Investors in collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.’s, were badly burned by increases in interest rates in 1994. Some of the factors are again present. Banks and other investors in the little-known trillion-dollar market could be set for a spill.

headline.main:
Peril for Products
Tied to Mortgages
headline.print_headline:
Peril for Products
Tied to Mortgages

byline.original: By AGNES T. CRANE and ANTONY CURRIE

abstract: As Toyota has issued its piecemeal recalls, the system for monitoring car safety across Europe has appeared similarly opaque and slow to react.
snippet: As Toyota has issued its piecemeal recalls, the system for monitoring car safety across Europe has appeared similarly opaque and slow to react.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  The first problems with sticking accelerators in some Toyotas surfaced more than a year ago in Britain and Ireland. But it was only Friday, long after a global recall began, that the European Commission issued its first consumer alert.

headline.main: A Slow Reaction to Toyota Illustrates Gaps in Europe
headline.print_headline: A Slow Reaction to Toyota Illustrates Gaps in Europe

byline.original: By James Kanter and Luke Browne

abstract: In recent months, the Japanese automaker has recalled about eight million cars worldwide over gas pedals that could stick or become caught on floor mats.
snippet: In recent months, the Japanese automaker has recalled about eight million cars worldwide over gas pedals that could stick or become caught on floor mats.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, the Japanese automaker has recalled about eight million cars worldwide over gas pedals that could stick or become caught on floor mats.
